      • where

        public static <T,P> Predicate<T> where(Fn<T,P> fn,
                       Predicate<? super P> predicate)
        Compose a predicate from taking the result of a function and apply it to another predicate. 
         fn(T) ∈ P
 p(P) ∈ {true, false}
 ƒ(T) = p(fn(T)) ∈ {true, false}

        This simple composition enables one to focus on writing functions for your particular domain, and reusing basic predicates provided by Motif.

        Type Parameters:
        P - The type of the predicate evaluating the function result.
        T - The type of the resulting predicate.
        Parameters:
        fn - The function which result will be evaluated by the predicate. Takes an argument of T
        predicate - Evaluates the result from the function, i.e. a value of P
        Returns:
        A predicate of T

      • both

        public static <T> Conjunction<T> both(Predicate<T> predicate)
        Create a AND-expression of several predicates, starting with the one given to this method.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The first predicate.
        Returns:
        a new predicate which may be used to build up an AND-expression by chaining the and(anotherPredicate) method.
        See Also:
        Conjunction, allOf(Predicate...)

      • all

        public static <E,I extends Iterable<E>> Predicate<I> all(Predicate<? super E> predicate)
        Evaluate if all elements satisfies a predicate, i.e. the Universal quantifier function. Note that the predicate
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate which will evaluate all elements.
        Returns:
        a predicate which evaluates to true if all elements evaluates to true by the given predicate, false if any evaluates to false.

      • exists

        public static <E,I extends Iterable<E>> Predicate<I> exists(Predicate<? super E> element)
        Evaluate if an element exists, i.e. the Existential quantifier function.
        Parameters:
        element - The existance-deciding predicate.
        Returns:
        a predicate which evaluates to true if any element evaluates to true by the given predicate, false otherwise.

      • extract

        @SafeVarargs
public static <T,E> Fn<T,Elements<E>> extract(Fn<? super T,? extends E>... extractors)
        A function to extract/derive several values from one object. The result of the extraction is an Elementss container of the least common supertype of the extractor Fns' return types.
        Parameters:
        extractors - the Fns which will extract values from each object passed to the function.
        Returns:
        the composed function which yields.

      • when

        public static <I,O> When<I,O> when(Predicate<? super I> condition,
                   Fn<I,O> fn)
        Creates a "guarded" Fn using a Predicate to evaluate if the argument should be passed to the wrapped Fn. The function created by this method is essentially this ternary expression: 
         condition(v) ? f(v) : null;
        To fall back to another value than null, call either .orElse(Fn) or .orElse(other) on the returned object.
        Parameters:
        condition - Only when this evaluates to true will the function argument be applied to the given Fn.
        fn - The Fn to apply if condition evaluates to true

      • first

        public static final <I,O> FnChain<I,O,O> first(Fn<I,O> fn)
        Compose a chain of several functions into one Fn, where the result of each function is passed to its successor, and the last will yield the actual result of the chain. Use .then(Fn) to append functions to the chain.

        Note: The chain does no internal inspection of the intermediate results passed to the next function, which means that any function which may return null, must have a null-safe successor function.

        Parameters:
        fn - The first function in the chain.
        Returns:
        the given function as the first function in a chain.

      • first

        public static final <I1,I2,O> Fn2Chain<I1,I2,O,O> first(Fn2<I1,I2,O> fn2)
        Compose a chain of several functions into one Fn2, where the result of each function is passed to its successor, and the last will yield the actual result of the chain. Use .then(Fn) to append functions to the chain.

        Note: The chain does no inspection of the intermediate results passed to the next function, which means that any function which may return null, must have a null-safe successor function.

        Parameters:
        fn2 - The first function in the chain.
        Returns:
        the given function as the first function in a chain.

      • first

        public static final RunnableChain first(Runnable runnable)
        Compose several Runnables as a single Runnable which will execute the given Runnables in sequence.
        Parameters:
        runnable - The first Runnable.
        Returns:
        the given Runnable as the first Runnable in a sequence.

      • first

        public static <V> DoChain<V> first(Do<V> action)
        Chain several Dos to be executed in sequence.
        Parameters:
        action - The first Do to execute.
        Returns:
        The given Do as the first Do in a sequence.

      • alwaysThrow

        public static <I1,I2,O> Throw<I1,I2,O> alwaysThrow(Exception ex)
        Create a function which always throw the given exception. If the exception is not a RuntimeException it will be wrapped as such.
        Parameters:
        ex - The exception to throw.
